comments.commentBody: It is unfortunate that immigration, embassy and customs officials (who know they hold a certain power over you) all too often misuse that power to make the customer serve them and not the way it should be, they serving the customer.

I dealt with a passport agent here in Denver.  We were renewing my daughter's passport.  She was under some minimum age when the passport we were renewing was issued.  She was over that age now.  The web site said I need not sign for her, but the agent said I had to.  I choose not to argue, despite the fact that the agent was wrong.  On my son's renewal (same set of facts) she took the opposite view.  I think they go to TSA school to ensure they inconsistently apply rules.  Fortunately, we won't have the same result when the government heavily intervenes in health care.

The TSA website explicitly states that knitting needles are permitted on board, but many knitters have felt the sting of a TSA agent who has no patience for knitting needles and have had to give up the needles and the yarn on them. Things like that are handled "at the agent's discretion." While I haven't personally been robbed of my needles, the stories of temperamental TSA agents make me do one of two things: bring an SASE to mail the knitting back to myself in case of a refusal, or simply not bring my knitting at all.

It's a shame what some people will do to feel powerful.
Props to the headline writer and Procol Harum fan!  Reminds me of a friend whose wife broke her elbow.  He asked of the elbow, "What's a crummy joint like you doing in a beautiful girl like this?"
Just wait till he's running your healthcare.
What a luxury to be able to vent to thousands of people when you have a bad experience.  :-) I feel your pain.
Promoted from the DMV.

My "ideal" Smart Phone would have a form factor similar to Motorola Devour.

What I would like is the following:

1. Large wide screen, similar to the iPhone
2. Slide-out, physical keyboard, similar to the Devour
3. Excellent connectivity to corporate email and calendar, similar to the Blackberry
4. Worldwide network capability
5. Good build-quality

Why is this phone not available now??

Those who rail against the Tea Party's stance on government spending are in denial but will perhaps wake up when their taxes rise excessively and/or when the nation declares bankruptcy. The current total unfunded indebtedness of Social Security and Medicare equals $106.4 trillion, which is more than double the total of the nation's private net worth. Those who are in their 20s should swell the ranks of the Tea Party since the outlook for you to receive Social Security or Medicare is pretty darn dim.

Yes, Bush added to the deficit with the cost of the Iraq War. But he also inherited a recession from Clinton (that surplus was bogus and borrowed from Social Security and other government funds), and Bush's tax cuts actually shifted more of the tax burden on the "rich" while cutting taxes on low-income earners.

Since his inauguration, Obama has added $2 trillion to the national debt, a feat that took Bush 4 years. Obama's "urgent" stimulus bill was passed on the promise that it would cap unemployment at 8% and "make or create" 3.5 million jobs. It has fulfilled neither promise; in fact, 3.8 million jobs have been lost since Obama signed the stimulus bill.

The health legislation will neither lower the costs of health care nor the costs of premiums, but it will increase taxes on individuals and businesses. In addition, it will add at least $2 trillion to the national debt.

Those in the Tea Party have legitimate complaints about escalating government spending. Mocking the Tea Party is easy; researching and studying the facts that prompted the growth of the movement requires a facile, discerning mind.

I'm proud to have a President whose earnings came from his own efforts and not primarily from inheritance. And further proud that he gave 1.7 million of the 6.9 million he earned to charity. And that he didn't use tax dodges.

Some in this country took in hundreds of millions or billions last year and did so mainly because they inherited monopoly ownership of something -- and gave less. By comparison, news stories of the divorce of the owners of the Los Angeles Dodgers say they have paid nothing in federal or state taxes for several years.

Is comparable data available for previous Presidents?
plus6sigma.......Amen!
It's simply laughable indeed.

The Tea Partyers have misdirected anger. There is anger about three things:

#1) We have an intelligent Black man in the WH and a lot of middle-age white men (the polls suggest these make the majority of Tea Party ralliers) just can not stand it . They absolutely can not stand it. (And BTW: Obama is highly intelligent... for the first time Gen Patraeus knows he has someone he can discuss the strategy of Iraq and Afghanistan with and formulate an exit plan that people in the Pentagon and WH will listen too. The former POTUS had no clue what Patraeus was talking about.)

#2) These people are angry because they want everything... security, infrastructure, retirement (SSA), medicare, etc etc etc... but they don't feel THEY should have to pay for it. Let someone else foot the bill. They are so angry, they can't even comprehend that in 2009 their taxes were actually lower than in 2008. They are so angry they can't comprehend that taxes are now lower across the board for the average middle aged American than they have been for over 50 years.

Lastly #3) I think Sarah Palin is still miffed she didn't get to speak on election night with John "Maverick" McCain - so she's trying her gosh golly darndest to be front and center now. Yep, you just "betcha" that's what this is really all about.

*Hope she remembered to file her taxes today... :)
Perhaps you have not lived in Chicago, but the dead have voted there for many years.

Mr. Cohen: I always have to read your columns several times because you include so many vast issues spanning the globe and then try to come up with what seems like a simplistic summing up comment. I wonder if my aging brain is unable to take it all in or is it like an overstuffed suitcase which when closed has bits and pieces of clothing sticking out. This time the following was a clue and something not quite neatly packed in that suitcase of a column:

"Prizing the future over the past was never an issue in America."

As usual, what exactly are you saying in this terse but huge thought? If you indeed meant to say America looks forward rather than dwelling on the past and if this is supposed to be healthy I take issue. The old saying about being forced to repeat history comes to mind. It also is a focal point that speaks for something that was nagging me and now my brain has cleared and it relates to the fact that nowhere in your column about the complicated relations between Israel and Palestine did you mention the role of the United States in all of their futures.

A recent comment was made by President Obama that he cannot resolve any Middle East issues until the two combatants come to some agreements. I think that a President and a Congress in this case has HUGE leverage regarding the money strings reaching across the globe but because of the star war military plans for the future of our country, Obama cannot involve himself in peace negotiations which would involve having to reign in Israel's nuclear warheads among other things. This was a jarring note at the recent Nuclear non-proliferation summit.

I think your column is the spin, and not my thinking. No matter how the living compare to the dead, the issues affecting us now remain the same and the only thing to remember about the history of the past, is that what didn't work before, ain't working now. It is time to change the rose colored glasses and begin to read between the lines even more to get at the truth. Otherwise we will begin to believe our own lofty rhetoric.

One fact about exponential growth (of population) is that the number of people alive today is approximately equal to the number of people who have ever been alive in all of human history (up to a constant factor). So however poetic, we the living are not necessarily in the minority.
Of course this perhaps makes your point even more telling. If the future could vote, it would far outvote all of human history!

Here is what I fear: it is already too late for this generation of Palestinians to make real peace. On the one hand, you have the daily humiliation of living in occupied territories and the soul-crushing humiliation of checkpoints and border crossings. On the other hand, you have poisonous Hamas propaganda that drills pernicious, anti-Jewish notions into the minds of young children.

Combine these two ingredients together and you have an entire generation of Palestinians who are so wedded to the memory of historical injustice and the identity of victimhood, that they just can't move on. Leaders like Fayyad are great, and he may yet secure some kind of peace. But, to keep peace, you need a population that has a certain confidence of mind - an ability to let go and move on.

Both the Israeli and the Palestinian leadership are to blame for this.

First, Mr Cohen, this column is, in my opinion, the best you have ever written. I congratulate you and, even more whole-heartedly, I thank you.

One sentence stood out for me: "A non-violent Palestinian approach is an eloquent way of saying today’s children matter more than olive groves three generations distant."

That is because the thought has gone through my mind ten thousand time, "What would what-was-Palestine look like if the Arabic-speakers there had as much military power as the Hebrew-speakers.?" Surely one of the most mind-boggling things about Israel, in the last 25 years especially, is the comparative sizes of the armaments available to the opposing sides. There has surely been nothing like it in the entire history of warfare. (Though the difference between what was available to the Apaches and the Sixth Cavalry may come close.) But that sentence I quoted struck me as a launching pad for a new kind of rivalry between the Israelis and the Palestinians, a contest in which both sides begin with equal resources - a contest to see which community can build a totally non-violent society first?

This may be nitpicking, but, due to population growth, it isn't clear to me that the living are actually a "minority."  World population has been growing rapidly, from about 1 billion in 1800 (and much less than that earlier on), to about 3 billion in 1960, to 6.7 billion today.  Most of the people born since 1960 are still alive, as are a fair portion of those born since 1940.  Looking at the numbers, if the living are in fact a minority, they are a very substantial minority, and it seems at least possible that they might be the majority.  I don't know if this has any bearing on the column's argument, but I thought I'd point it out.

Republicans are getting bolder and bolder with their lies. Why? Because they can count on the conservative media (Fox, talk radio, etc.) to make sure the faithful don't ever learn that they are lies. Anybody in the rest of the media who calls them on it, like Paul Krugman, will just be called liberal liars. The Republican base will sleep soundly, thinking they are still right. Those in the middle won't know what to make of it, and won't choose sides. Thus the truth and the lie get equal play. Given that, why not employ the big lie?

There is very little to disagree with Dr. Krugman today.  The financial institutions need to be rescued in case of a crisis, and his argument for seizing and fixing them is convincing.  I only wish that Dr. Krugman would explicitly state that rescuing financial institutions does not include enriching the criminal management and the risk-taking shareholders.  The looted Americans would have liked it if the wise one had strongly also argued for criminal indictments and jail terms for the Dimons, Blankfeins, Pandits, etc.

"It’s a truly shameless performance: Mr. McConnell is pretending to stand up for taxpayers against Wall Street while in fact doing just the opposite."

I love the English language and the way that on occasion a word and its apparent opposite can actually mean the same thing - that sentence reminds me of one such anomaly. ShameLESS and ShameFUL are the same - they are both exactly right adjectives to attach to Senator McConnell's behavior IMHO - most of the time, in fact.

The next time you criticize a liberal/democrat will be your first.

Republican=Bad
Democrat/Liberal=Good

This is getting both monotonous and repetitive with you and your columns. If you want to offer up some good advice that is simply not "democratic" talking points then I would be happen to listen to what you have to say. But for now this is nothing but drivel and frankly sir enough is enough.

Watching McConnell, one yearns the somewhat recent movie involving aliens attacking DC and starring Jcak Nicholson could be re-made with the Senator being one of the first to oppose the aliens :)

McConnell's toadying obfuscations are the object lesson in what has been wrong with the GOP since 1992 - either he knows what he is trying to sell to the public is tripe or, worse, he doesn't know.

You wrote

"The Obama administration wants tighter regulation of derivatives, while Republicans are opposed. And that tells you everything you need to know."

That's not even rational Paul. There's lots more thst people need to know; like where do those bankers contribute their political dollars? ; and who has been in charge of evrything in American politics while the bankers have become richer than Roman kings?

The answer to both is : Obama and the Democrats in Congress.
